div.l: For with þe falle he brosten hadde his arme
But stonde he most vnto his owne harme
For whan he spak he was a non bore down̄
With hynde Nicholas and Alisoıı̄un
Þey tolden every man þat he was wode
He was a gast so of Noes flode NoNoes flodeNoes flode
Þorough fantesye þat of his vanitee
He hed y bought him knedyng tobbes thre
And hedde hem honged in þe rofe above
And þat he preyed him for goddes love
To sitten in þe roof ꝑpar compaignye
Þe folke gan laughen at his fantasie
Into þe roof þey kyken and þey gape
And turneden al his harme vnto a Iape
It was for nought ne man his reson herde
For what so þat þis Carpenter answerde
With othes grete he was so sworn a doun
Þat he was holden wodde þorough al þe town
For every clerk anon righ hilde with other
He seide þe man was wode my leve brother
And euꝰery with gan laughen at þis stryf
Þus swyved was þe Carpenter wyf
For al his kepyng and his Ialousye
And Absolon hath kist hir nether ye
And Nicholas was skalded in þe towte
Þis tale is doūn god save al þe rowte
Here endeþ þe Millers tale . And
Begynneth þe ꝓprologe of þe Reues tale
Whan folke han laughen at þis nyce cas
Of Absolon and hende Nicholas
Dyverce folke diuersly þey seyde
But for þe more part þey lough and pleyede
Ne at his tale y saugh no man hȳm greve
But it were only Oswalde þe Reve
By cause he was of carpenter crafte
Alitel Ire is in his hert lefte
He gan to crocche and blamed it a lyte
Sothyk qduod he ful wel coude y you quyte
With bleryng of a proud Milwardys ye
If þat me liste to speke of Ribaudye
